content.source_1: Jacob N. Shapiro, The Terrorist’s Dilemma: Managing Violent Covert Organizations (Princeton University Press, 2013) — Analysis of internal documents from militant groups shows that publicity is integral to claiming credit, signaling strength, recruiting, and fundraising; limiting attention reduces the strategic payoff of attacks, supporting restrictions on publicity.
content.source_2: Michael Jetter, “The effect of media attention on terrorism,” Journal of Public Economics (2017) — Econometric evidence (using exogenous variation in news crowd-out) finds that greater mainstream media coverage is followed by more terrorist attacks, suggesting a causal contagion effect and providing a rationale for curbing sensational coverage.
content.source_3: UN Human Rights Committee, General Comment No. 34 on Article 19 (CCPR/C/GC/34, 2011) — Affirms that blanket bans on reporting are incompatible with freedom of expression; warns that states often invoke “terrorism” to suppress legitimate journalism and dissent, arguing against prohibiting publicity as overbroad and prone to abuse.
content.source_4: J.M. Berger and Jonathon Morgan, The ISIS Twitter Census (Brookings Institution, 2015) — Documents that sustained account suspensions and moderation significantly reduced ISIS’s reach and audience growth on Twitter; indicates that limiting publicity on platforms can diminish extremist propaganda dissemination.
content.source_5: City of Boston and Commonwealth of Massachusetts, After-Action Report for the Response to the 2013 Boston Marathon Bombings (2014) — Highlights the value of robust public information and media partnerships for safety alerts and suspect identification during a terrorist incident, implying that some publicity is necessary for public protection and accountability.
